critique: The document is a revocation of a previous executive order, which removes restrictions on voluntary enlistments in the armed forces. This action could be interpreted in several ways depending on the context of the time (August 29, 1945, just after the end of WWII). It could be seen as promoting individual liberty by allowing people to choose to enlist, or as a move to maintain a strong military. Given the historical context, the emphasis is likely on maintaining military strength during the post-war period. There is no clear indication of bias regarding immigration, federalism, economic regulation, or social inclusion. The order seems to expand executive power by revoking a previous order.
